title: I'm a Black single mother. The 'pro-life' movement didn't support me
description: Abortion was not consistent with my values. But the 'pro-life' movement did not offer me any assistance when I raised my child.
text_headers:
I became a doctor as a single Black mom. The 'pro-life' movement didn't help me.
Abortion was not consistent with my values. But the anti-abortion movement did not offer me any assistance when I raised my child.

But the anti-abortion movement did not offer me any assistance when I raised my child.Dr. Carmen BlackOpinion contributorToday, I am an African American woman descended from enslaved persons, who became a physician and faculty at Yale University. Most important, I am “Mom," a fiercely proud single Black mother raising the world’s most amazing daughters.  In 2008, I was just Carmen – a college graduate with dreams of becoming a physician who was petrified at the sight of a little blue plus sign on a home pregnancy test. Worse, I knew that there would be no paternal support. I vividly remember how, as I contemplated the meaning of that little blue plus sign, I lingered at the kitchen table staring blankly at the phone book. As I nervously flipped the yellow pages to adoption agencies, I first came across a different option: abortion.Help Terms of Service Subscription Terms & Conditions Privacy Policy Our Ethical Principles Responsible Disclosure Site Map Your Privacy Choices© 2024 USA TODAY, a division of Gannett Satellite Information Network, LLC.
